message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms match those of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency. The increased muscle tone and self-injurious behavior are classic symptoms of this disorder. The laboratory findings also indicate increased uric acid, which is a hallmark of HPRT deficiency. Options (A), (B), and (D) are not associated with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by a hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency. FMR1 gene mutation is associated with Fragile X syndrome, Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency is associated with maple syrup urine disease, and microdeletion of paternal chromosome 15 is associated with Prader-Willi syndrome, but none of these conditions match the patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT). The self-injurious behavior and developmental delays are characteristic of this condition. None of the other options listed would cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including delay in developmental milestones, self-injury, and increased muscle tone, suggest Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by a hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency. The laboratory studies also show elevated uric acid, which is a characteristic feature of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. The other options listed are genetic disorders that can cause developmental delay but do not have the characteristic features of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest that the most likely cause is Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency (HGPRT deficiency), also known as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This is a genetic disorder that affects muscle tone and behavior, causing developmental delay and self-injurious behavior. The laboratory result of high uric acid levels is also consistent with this diagnosis. FMR1 gene mutation causes Fragile X syndrome, which presents with intellectual disability, large ears, and prominent forehead. Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency causes maple syrup urine disease and presents with neurological symptoms, such as seizures and coma, along with a distinctive sweet odor in urine. Microdeletion of paternal chromosome 15 causes Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with developmental delay, hypotonia, and hyperphagia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Lesch-Nyhan syndrome which is caused by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency. This enzyme is necessary for recycling purines in the body, and lack of it leads to hyperuricemia and self-injurious behaviors. The lab results also show elevated uric acid levels. FMR1 gene mutation causes fragile X syndrome, Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency causes maple syrup urine disease, and microdeletion of paternal chromosome 15 causes Prader-Willi syndrome, none of which fit the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the most likely cause is Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency (also known as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome), which is characterized by developmental delays, self-injurious behavior, and increased muscle tone. FMR1 gene mutation is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which typically presents with intellectual disability and behavioral problems but not self-injury. Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency and Microdeletion of paternal chromosome 15 are both associated with developmental delays but without the specific self-injurious behavior seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) enzyme. This deficiency leads to neurological symptoms such as delay in developmental milestones, self-injurious behavior, and increased muscle tone, as well as laboratory findings such as elevated uric acid levels. FMR1 gene mutation is associated with fragile X syndrome, which typically manifests with intellectual disability, behavioral problems, and physical features such as a long face and large ears. Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency and microdeletion of paternal chromosome 15 are both rare genetic conditions that can lead to developmental delay and neurological symptoms, but they are not consistent with the specific symptoms and laboratory findings in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s developmental delays, involuntary movements, and laboratory values suggest Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency, also known as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. FMR1 gene mutation is associated with fragile X syndrome, characterized by intellectual and developmental disabilities. Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency can cause developmental delay, seizures, and coma. Microdeletion of the paternal chromosome 15 can cause Prader-Willi syndrome, characterized by intellectual disability, hyperphagia, obesity, and hypotonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest that the most likely cause is hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) deficiency, also known as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This is characterized by delayed developmental milestones, self-injurious behavior such as head-banging, and increased muscle tone. The laboratory findings show elevated uric acid levels, which are typical in this condition. FMR1 gene mutation is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which presents with intellectual disability and behavioral problems but not with self-injurious behavior. Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency and microdeletion of paternal chromosome 15 are not associated with the symptoms and laboratory findings seen in this patient.
